title: B12 Deficiency Neuropathy
icd10: G32.0 (Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord in diseases classified elsewhere)
D51.0 (Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia due to intrinsic factor deficiency)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of neurological manifestations of vitamin B12 deficiency including peripheral neuropathy, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, and cognitive changes. Includes diagnosis, treatment, monitoring of neurological recovery, and identification of underlying etiology (pernicious anemia, malabsorption, dietary deficiency). Excludes pure hematologic B12 deficiency without neurological involvement. For general peripheral neuropathy workup, see the Peripheral Neuropathy template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Confirm deficiency; <200 pg/mL diagnostic; 200-400 pg/mL borderline
Elevated in B12 deficiency; more sensitive than serum B12; essential if B12 200-400 pg/mL
Elevated in B12 and folate deficiency; helps confirm metabolic B12 deficiency
Macrocytic anemia (MCV >100); hypersegmented neutrophils; pancytopenia possible
Macro-ovalocytes, hypersegmented neutrophils (>=5 lobes); megaloblastic changes
Low in megaloblastic anemia; rises within 5-7 days of treatment (reticulocyte crisis)
Renal dysfunction affects MMA interpretation; LDH elevated in megaloblastic anemia; electrolytes
Rule out concurrent folate deficiency; folate replacement alone may worsen neurological B12 deficiency
Markedly elevated in megaloblastic anemia due to intramedullary hemolysis
Autoimmune thyroid disease co-occurs with pernicious anemia
Co-existing iron deficiency may mask macrocytosis; combined deficiency common

Extended Workup (Etiology).rationale: Highly specific (>95%) for pernicious anemia; sensitivity ~50-70%
Sensitive (~80-90%) but less specific for pernicious anemia; positive in other autoimmune conditions
Elevated in pernicious anemia due to achlorhydria; helps confirm autoimmune gastritis
Celiac disease screening; celiac causes B12 malabsorption at terminal ileum
IgA deficiency causes false-negative celiac serologies
Biologically active B12 fraction; may detect early deficiency before total B12 falls
Low pepsinogen I in autoimmune atrophic gastritis; pepsinogen I/II ratio <3 suggests atrophic gastritis
H. pylori can cause B12 malabsorption; may coexist with pernicious anemia
HIV causes B12 malabsorption and neuropathy
Copper deficiency mimics B12 deficiency myeloneuropathy; concurrent deficiency possible post-bariatric surgery
Excess zinc supplementation causes copper deficiency; common etiology of copper-deficient myelopathy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Classic test for pernicious anemia; rarely performed; replaced by IF antibodies and MMA
Urine MMA may be more reliable in renal insufficiency than serum MMA
Rare genetic deficiency causing functional B12 deficiency with normal serum B12
Inborn errors of cobalamin metabolism; young patients with B12-resistant neuropathy
If concurrent autoimmune neuropathy suspected (CIDP, MMN); may coexist
If subacute onset, weight loss, smoking; paraneoplastic myelopathy mimics SCD
Monoclonal gammopathy can cause neuropathy mimicking B12 deficiency

Essential/First-line.item: MRI spine (cervical and thoracic) with and without contrast (CPT 72141, 72146)
Essential/First-line.timing: URGENT if myelopathy symptoms; ROUTINE if neuropathy only
Essential/First-line.target: Subacute combined degeneration: bilateral symmetric T2 hyperintensity in posterior columns ("inverted V sign" on axial); may involve lateral columns
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 for gadolinium; pacemaker; metal implants

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; 3-4 weeks after symptom onset optimal for Wallerian degeneration detection
Essential/First-line.target: Axonal sensorimotor polyneuropathy; reduced sensory amplitudes more than motor; sural nerve often affected early

Extended.target: White matter changes; cerebral atrophy (chronic); exclude other causes of cognitive decline

Extended.timing: If clinical myelopathy suspected but MRI equivocal
Extended.target: Prolonged central conduction time confirming posterior column dysfunction

Extended.timing: If visual symptoms or optic neuropathy suspected
If pernicious anemia confirmed; screen for atrophic gastritis and gastric carcinoid
Extended.target: Atrophic gastritis; intestinal metaplasia; rule out gastric carcinoid/adenocarcinoma

Rare/Specialized.timing: If small bowel malabsorption suspected (celiac, Crohn, bacterial overgrowth)
If small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) suspected as cause of malabsorption
If small fiber neuropathy component suspected; normal NCS with ongoing pain

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.indication: Confirmed or suspected B12 deficiency with neurological symptoms; preferred parenteral route

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg IM weekly x 4 weeks, then 1000 mcg IM monthly indefinitely

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.contraindications: Cobalt or cobalamin hypersensitivity (rare); Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (relative)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.monitoring: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7 (reticulocyte crisis confirms response); B12 and MMA at 1-2 months; CBC at 1-2 months; potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis)

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.indication: Alternative to cyanocobalamin; longer-acting; preferred in some countries; better for cyanide toxicity

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg IM daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg IM every other day x 2 weeks, then 1000 mcg IM monthly indefinitely

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.contraindications: Cobalt or cobalamin hypersensitivity (rare); Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (relative)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.monitoring: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7; B12 and MMA at 1-2 months; CBC at 1-2 months; potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis)

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.indication: If IM injection contraindicated (anticoagulation, thrombocytopenia) or patient preference

dosing.instructions: 1000 mcg SC daily x 7 days, then 1000 mcg SC weekly x 4 weeks, then 1000 mcg SC monthly indefinitely

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.contraindications: Cobalt or cobalamin hypersensitivity (rare); Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (relative)
Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.monitoring: Reticulocyte count at day 5-7; B12 and MMA at 1-2 months; CBC at 1-2 months; potassium during first 48 hours (hypokalemia from erythropoiesis)

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.indication: Prevent hypokalemia during B12 replacement; erythropoiesis consumes potassium

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mEq PO daily; monitor potassium q12-24h during first 48 hours of B12 replacement; supplement if K <3.5 mEq/L

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.monitoring: Potassium levels q12-24h during initial treatment

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.indication: Correct hypomagnesemia; magnesium required for enzymatic reactions involving B12

dosing.instructions: 2 g IV over 2 hours if Mg <1.5 mg/dL; then oral magnesium oxide 400 mg PO daily

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.monitoring: Magnesium levels; cardiac monitoring during IV infusion

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.indication: Correct concurrent folate deficiency; MUST give with B12 to avoid masking B12 deficiency

dosing.instructions: 1 mg PO daily; NEVER give folate without B12 in suspected B12 deficiency (may worsen neurological damage)

Acute/Emergent - B12 Replacement.monitoring: Ensure B12 is being co-administered; reticulocyte count

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.indication: Neuropathic pain (first-line); burning, tingling, shooting pain

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg qHS; titrate by 300 mg every 1-3 days to TID dosing; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; adjust for renal function (CrCl 30-59: max 1400 mg/day; CrCl 15-29: max 700 mg/day; CrCl <15: max 300 mg/day)

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust required); respiratory depression with opioids
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Sedation, dizziness, peripheral edema; taper to discontinue (do not stop abruptly)

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg BID; may increase to 150 mg BID after 1 week; max 300 mg BID (600 mg/day); adjust for renal function (CrCl <60: reduce dose); Schedule V controlled substance

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust required); history of substance abuse (relative)
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Sedation, weight gain, peripheral edema; dizziness; taper to discontinue

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.indication: Neuropathic pain (first-line); especially effective for painful neuropathy with comorbid depression

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg daily x 1 week; increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Hepatic impairment; CrCl <30; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Nausea (usually transient); BP monitoring; discontinuation syndrome (taper over 2+ weeks)

dosing.instructions: Start 37.5 mg daily; increase by 75 mg every 4-7 days; target 150 mg daily; max 225 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: BP monitoring; serotonin syndrome; discontinuation syndrome (taper over 2+ weeks)

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line); useful for concurrent insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects; sedation; weight gain

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.indication: Neuropathic pain (second-line); fewer anticholinergic effects than amitriptyline

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg qHS; increase by 10-25 mg weekly; max 150 mg qHS

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Cardiac conduction abnormality; recent MI; urinary retention; narrow-angle glaucoma; elderly
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: ECG if dose >100 mg/day; anticholinergic effects (fewer than amitriptyline); sedation

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.indication: Localized neuropathic pain in feet or hands

dosing.instructions: Apply thin layer TID-QID to affected area; takes 2-4 weeks for full effect; wash hands thoroughly after application

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Open wounds; avoid eyes and mucous membranes
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Initial burning sensation (decreases with continued use); do not apply to broken skin

dosing.instructions: Apply 1-3 patches to painful area for 12 hours on, 12 hours off; max 3 patches simultaneously

Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; application to broken skin
Symptomatic Treatments - Neuropathic Pai.monitoring: Minimal systemic absorption; local skin irritation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Moderate neuropathic pain refractory to first-line agents

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg q6h PRN; may increase to 100 mg q6h; max 400 mg/day; ER formulation 100-300 mg daily

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Seizure disorder; concurrent MAOIs; concurrent SSRIs/SNRIs (serotonin syndrome risk)
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Seizure risk; serotonin syndrome; dependence (Schedule IV); constipation

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Localized neuropathic pain refractory to standard topical therapy

dosing.instructions: Applied by healthcare provider for 30-60 minutes; may repeat every 3 months; pretreat area with topical lidocaine

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: BP during application; pain during and after application; must be applied in clinical setting

Second-line/Refractory.item: High-dose oral B12 (if parenteral not tolerated)
Second-line/Refractory.indication: B12 replacement when injections refused or contraindicated; compliance concerns

doseOptions.orderSentence: High-dose oral B12 (if parenteral not tolerated) 1000 mcg PO

dosing.instructions: 1000-2000 mcg PO daily; ~1% absorbed passively independent of intrinsic factor; may be adequate for mild deficiency; monitor closely
dosing.orderSentence: High-dose oral B12 (if parenteral not tolerated) 1000 mcg PO

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: B12 and MMA levels at 2-3 months to confirm adequate absorption; if MMA remains elevated, switch to parenteral

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Alternative oral B12 formulation; may have improved bioavailability

dosing.instructions: 1000-5000 mcg sublingual daily; dissolve under tongue; efficacy data limited compared to IM

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: B12 and MMA levels at 2-3 months; switch to parenteral if inadequate response

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for confirmation of B12 deficiency neuropathy and monitoring of neurological recovery
Hematology referral for evaluation of persistent macrocytic anemia or pancytopenia not responding to B12 replacement
Gastroenterology referral for EGD and evaluation of pernicious anemia, atrophic gastritis, or malabsorption etiology
Physical therapy for gait training, balance exercises, and fall prevention given proprioceptive loss and sensory ataxia
Occupational therapy for hand function optimization and adaptive equipment if fine motor impairment from neuropathy
Endocrinology referral for evaluation of concurrent autoimmune thyroid disease (autoimmune polyglandular syndrome)
Nutrition/Dietitian referral for dietary counseling regarding B12-rich foods, especially for vegans, vegetarians, and post-bariatric patients
Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first- and second-line agents after adequate B12 replacement
Neuropsychological testing for cognitive assessment if persistent cognitive impairment despite B12 normalization
Social work consult for assistance with self-injection training, medication access, and disability resources

Patient Instructions.item: B12 injections are lifelong if pernicious anemia is the cause; stopping injections will cause neuropathy to recur and worsen
Neurological symptoms may take 3-12 months to improve after starting B12 replacement; improvement depends on duration and severity of deficiency before treatment
Return immediately if worsening weakness, difficulty walking, or new bladder/bowel dysfunction develops (may indicate progressive myelopathy requiring urgent evaluation)
If self-administering B12 injections, use proper IM technique and rotate injection sites (outer thigh or deltoid); attend injection training with nursing
Do not take folate supplements without B12 as folate alone may mask B12 deficiency while neurological damage continues to progress
Inspect feet daily for cuts, blisters, or wounds using a mirror for soles; impaired sensation increases injury risk
Use night lights, handrails, and remove throw rugs to prevent falls from impaired balance and proprioception
Test bath water temperature with elbow before entering as impaired sensation increases burn risk
Neuropathic pain medications take 2-4 weeks to reach full effect; do not stop gabapentin or pregabalin abruptly
Report new numbness, tingling, or weakness to your neurologist as this may indicate inadequate treatment or alternative diagnosis
If vegan or vegetarian, lifelong B12 supplementation is required as plant-based diets contain no natural B12

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Complete alcohol cessation as alcohol independently causes neuropathy and worsens B12 malabsorption
Smoking cessation to improve vascular health and support nerve recovery
Dietary sources of B12: meat, fish, eggs, dairy, fortified cereals; supplement if dietary intake insufficient
Fall prevention: remove throw rugs, ensure adequate lighting, install grab bars, use assistive devices for sensory ataxia and proprioceptive loss
Regular exercise as tolerated (walking, swimming, stationary bike) to maintain strength and cardiovascular health; avoid exercises requiring intact proprioception without supervision
Avoid excessive vitamin B6 supplementation (>100 mg/day) which independently causes peripheral neuropathy
Annual screening for gastric carcinoid/adenocarcinoma if pernicious anemia confirmed (3-fold increased risk of gastric cancer)
Metformin users: annual B12 screening as metformin reduces B12 absorption by 10-30%
Review medications for B12-lowering agents: proton pump inhibitors, H2 blockers, metformin, colchicine, nitrous oxide exposure
Nitrous oxide avoidance: inform anesthesia team of B12 deficiency before any surgical procedures as N2O irreversibly oxidizes B12 and precipitates acute neurological deterioration

differential.features: Nearly identical to B12 SCD clinically; often post-bariatric surgery or zinc excess; may co-occur with B12 deficiency
differential.tests: Serum copper, ceruloplasmin; zinc level; may have neutropenia/anemia without macrocytosis

differential.features: Length-dependent symmetric sensory neuropathy; no myelopathy; burning pain common
differential.tests: HbA1c, fasting glucose, OGTT; NCS shows axonal polyneuropathy; no posterior column findings on MRI

differential.features: Demyelinating lesions; relapsing-remitting course; dissemination in time and space; young females
differential.tests: MRI brain/spine shows periventricular lesions; CSF oligoclonal bands; normal B12 and MMA

differential.features: Compressive myelopathy; neck pain; upper motor neuron signs in lower extremities
differential.tests: MRI cervical spine shows structural compression; B12 and MMA normal

differential.features: Similar posterior column involvement; immunocompromised; often with concurrent neuropathy
differential.tests: HIV testing; CD4 count; may coexist with B12 deficiency

differential.features: Posterior column dysfunction; lightning pains; Argyll Robertson pupils; may have concurrent neuropathy
Progressive or relapsing proximal and distal weakness; areflexia; demyelinating pattern on NCS
differential.tests: NCS shows demyelination (not axonal); CSF elevated protein; nerve enlargement on ultrasound

differential.features: Similar megaloblastic anemia; neuropathy less prominent; no SCD typically
differential.tests: Normal MMA; elevated homocysteine; low serum/RBC folate; B12 normal

differential.features: Progressive sensory ataxia; cardiomyopathy; onset in youth; autosomal recessive
differential.tests: Genetic testing (GAA trinucleotide repeat); normal B12

differential.features: Slowly progressive spastic paraparesis; family history; no sensory loss typically
differential.tests: Genetic testing; no posterior column involvement; B12 normal

differential.features: Acute/subacute SCD-like syndrome; often in B12-deficient patients; recreational N2O use
differential.tests: History of N2O exposure; B12 may be normal or low; MMA elevated; rapid onset

differential.features: Subacute onset; weight loss; smoking history; may affect posterior columns
Spinocerebellar ataxia; proprioceptive loss; may mimic SCD; fat malabsorption
differential.tests: Serum vitamin E level; fat-soluble vitamin panel

Parenteral B12 replacement for neurological B12 deficiency

Neurological damage may be irreversible if treatment delayed >6 months
Gabapentin, pregabalin, duloxetine first-line for neuropathic pain
Folate supplementation without B12 may worsen neurological manifestations

Acute or subacute myelopathy (gait ataxia, spasticity, weakness); inability to ambulate safely; severe pancytopenia requiring monitoring; need for frequent electrolyte monitoring during initial B12 replacement; concurrent acute illness complicating management; falls requiring inpatient rehabilitation assessment

Severe symptomatic anemia requiring transfusion with hemodynamic instability; high-output cardiac failure from severe anemia; severe hypokalemia with cardiac monitoring need during B12 replacement; respiratory compromise from severe weakness
